Ottawa, September 8, 1943.

Mr. A. D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.

In your agency report for August the suggestion is made that the opening and closing of Indian day schools be adjusted in future to conform with the dates of other schools in Ontario.

In this connection may I refer you to circular C-150-48, copy of which I am sending forward herewith. You will note that the instruction with respect to the opening and closing of Indian day schools in this circular is clear and explicit, and it is the duty and responsibility of our Indian agents to see that these instructions are obeyed by our teachers. Any attempt on the part of this Department to have our Indian day schools open and close on the same dates as public and separate schools throughout the Dominion would lead to endless confusion, for the simple reason that opening and closing dates differ in a number of the provinces. We are operating our schools this year on a 10-month rather than a 9-month basis, in response to requests received from Indian day school teachers. Teachers should be reminded, therefore, that it is their duty to see that their schools operate for the full teaching period. It is unnecessary to add that the holidays of Civil Servants and other government employees have been substantially reduced during the war period. In view of this fact, it would scarcely be fair for teachers to ask for holidays other than the holidays for which provision is made in the published regulations.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Encl.
Deseronto, Ont. October 9th 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Please find enclosed Day School Returns for the September quarter for the four day schools of Tyendinaga Indian Agency. The attendance at Western and Central schools has not been good and the R.C.M. Police have been requested to check on the absentees.

In acknowledging your letter 34-1-1 of September 8th in connection with the suggestion contained in my agency report for the month of August, I would advise that this office and all schools have a copy of your circular and that schools are and have been operated in accordance with the instructions contained therein and are thoroughly understood.

The local teachers are very pleased that the Department has seen fit to increase the academic year from a nine to a ten-months basis, with the corresponding addition in salary and which should give them an increased incentive in carrying out their duties.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Deseronto, Ontario, May 18th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

On my visit to Central Indian Day School on May 15th, Mrs. Eva Brant, temporary teacher at that school, informed me that she would not continue teaching after June 30th next, and that it would be necessary to procure another teacher.

Mrs. Brant's husband works a one hundred acre farm, and through lack of help has been inconvenienced during the period Mrs. Brant has been teaching, and this woman is needed at her home.

Unless the Department has a teacher in view suitable for this position, it is suggested that an advertisement be entered in the Belleville and Kingston papers for a week requesting applications. I would wish your authority to insert this advertisement and would you also inform me of the salary to be paid to a proper qualified teacher.

If a suitable applicant cannot be obtained in this manner, I would then consider that Miss Jean Schell, now on leave of absence as teacher of this school, be requested to resume her duties as teacher, as I personally consider that as a teacher her services would be just as important as those in which she is now engaged in a munition factory.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 22, 1944.

Mr. A.D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, in which you advise that Mrs. Eva Brant intends to give up duties at the Tyendinaga Central School at the end of the current academic year.

Please consult the Public School Inspector, Mr. A.W. McGuire, with a view to ascertaining if he has any teachers in mind that he could suggest. Salary will be allowed at the rate of $90, plus bonus of 17%, which means a total of $105.30.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Mr. A. D. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Moore:

In February of this year I was appointed Inspector of the joint inspectorate of Centre and South Hastings. Tyendinaga was separated from Centre Hastings and joined to Lennox, where Mr. K. O. Birkin of Napanee is Inspector. I fully expected that Mr. Birkin would be appointed to inspect the Indian schools in Tyendinaga. In fact, I was given to understand at the Department of Education in Toronto that the authorities at Ottawa would be asked to make the change. I am surprised to learn that there has been any delay in the matter.

Dr. V. K. Greer, Superintendent of Elementary Education, at the Ontario Department of Education, can supply you with further information.

Yours sincerely,

A. W. McGuiire
Ottawa,
June 15, 1944.

REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF SEPTEMBER, 1944

Schools;

The attendance at the schools was only fair during September, many of the older children being kept at home to assist in harvesting canning crops, due to the shortage of adult help. Mr. Birkin, Napanee, Public School Inspector who has inspected the Reserve Schools during 1943-44 has been transferred to Peterborough for one year and Mr. Mackles, Belleville, Inspector of the South Hastings District, has taken over that portion of Mr. Birkin's territory that includes the Tyendinaga Reserve Schools.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTHS OF OCTOBER AND NOVEMBER, 1944.

Schools:

The reports of the teachers show that the attendance at Central and Mission schools has steadily improved, while that of Eastern School has maintained its usual good level. Good reports have been received of these Indian pupils attending Shannonville and Milltown white schools as they are attending regular and making good progress, possibly being due to the new environment.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH DECEMBER, 1944.

Schools;

The attendance at the Agency schools during December was low, due to the severe weather and storms. The teachers were able to get to their schools so that Eastern School was closed one day, Central one day and Mission two days. The reports of the teachers for December show that there are a considerable number of pupils suffering from colds and at Eastern School, a number were absent from skin diseases, a condition that has been hard to clean up at this school. Cod Liver Oil was delivered to the schools in late November and teachers instructed to see that the children received the same. During December there was a considerable falling off in the attendance of Indian pupils to the Shannonville and Milltown white schools, due to inclement weather and sickness.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Schools: The school attendance during June quarter has been fairly good, but in spite of the efforts of this office and local Reserve organizations, the attendance has never been brought to a maximum and it is anticipated some better results will be obtained in the future on account of family allowances being paid to Indians. The teachers report a moderate number of cases of head and body lice, also the odd case of skin disease in which it has been necessary to order the children home for attention and treatment. Four pupils from Eastern, all that tried, have passed their Entrance examinations and two of these at least have expressed a desire to attend the Local High School; the other two are making their own arrangements to attend Vocational School at Belleville. Two pupils from Central passed their Entrance Exams and one girl is expecting to continue to High School at Deseronto. As previously reported, the co-operation from the R.C.M.P. and Special Constable in their duties as truant officers has been poor, lack of which can be attributed to the extra duties placed on the police on account of the war, which limits the time available for duties on the Reserve. It is expected these officers will give more supervision from this time on and that the parents will be closely checked in connection with the poor and irregular attendance of children of school age. For two days, June 19 and 20, senior pupils of all Reserve schools attended the Homemakers Club convention and heard addresses concerning Family Allowances, nutrition and medical care, school attendance, etc., from which they should derive considerable benefit in future. Manual training and sewing work at Eastern school has progressed well but has lagged some at Mission and Central schools, due partially to the indifference of the teachers in not procuring materials as was authorized. It is suggested that some definite graduation ceremony be established annually for Indian pupils who pass their Entrance examinations and at this gathering the children receive their entrance diplomas and also be capped and gowned. Such a procedure would be of some incentive for pupils to at least get their entrance and presentation of their certificates could be made by an official of the Department or some prominent local school inspector or public official. Gowns and mortar boards are inexpensive and could be supplied by the Department on a loan basis and be available yearly.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 1, 1945.

Dear Sir:

I have just reviewed the September quarter return of the Tyendinaga Central School. It shows an enrolment of 22 with an average attendance of 11.

The Eastern School has an enrolment of 33 and an average attendance of 25; while the enrolment at the Mission School is shown as 30 with an average attendance of 18.

You will note from the above figures that the average attendance at the Central School for the month of September is approximately 50%, but the percentage at the other schools is higher. In all three cases and especially in the case of the Central School these average attendances are not very satisfactory. We had hoped that with the payment of family allowances the average attendance at the Tyendinaga Schools, which has been so bad for many years, would improve. You have already been given specific instructions regarding the action to be taken in regard to family allowances in the event of children of school age not being enrolled or in the case of children who are enrolled but do not attend regularly. This matter should be again brought to the attention of the Tyendinaga Council at their next meeting, because fifty per cent attendances are not consistent with the payment of family allowances.

It is rather interesting to note that the average attendance at the Central School is the smallest, while the teacher at this school applied recently for

Mr. A. D. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.
an increase in salary. While the parents may be indifferent, it is reasonable to expect that the teacher should be sufficiently interested to encourage the parents to send their children.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Deseronto, Ontario, November 20, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I would acknowledge your letter of November 1st in connection with the attendance during September of Indian pupils at the three Day Schools of Tyendinaga Reserve and would state that the attendance during September of each year has always been fairly low due to the fact that a number of pupils are kept out of school to assist in the harvesting of tomato and other canning crops.

The reports made by the teachers to this office for the month of October show the following enrollments and average attendance:

Eastern Day School-Enrollment-36- Average Attendance 84.92%
Mission Day School- " -27- " " 82%
Central Day School- " -22- " " 75.25%

and while these averages could still be improved on, they are very fair and, as children are no longer needed to assist in harvesting crops, there should still be more improvement for the month of November.

Under separate cover you are being advised of the resignation of the teacher of Mission Day School and, if no replacement is secured, it will create an awkward situation and I am of the belief that, to retain good teachers, the Department will have to increase salaries to procure satisfactory employees and thereby bring salaries of teachers of Indian Day Schools in harmony with those paid teachers of white rural schools. It is also considered that a teacher receiving an adequate salary will give more satisfactory service and that more demand can be made on the services of a satisfied employee.

ADM/JMcV

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Deseronto, Ontario, March 14, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Francis Thompson,
Training School, Bowmanville.

The above noted boy, aged twelve years, whose parents are claimed to be Isaac and Gladys Thompson of unknown address, was committed by a Sudbury Magistrate to the Ontario Training School for Boys, Bowmanville, and, at the time of the boy's trial at Sudbury, the constable, giving evidence, stated he was not a Treaty Indian.

In December, last, this boy was released from the Bowmanville School to Peter Joe Brant, Indian resident of Tyendinaga Reserve, on the condition that Brant supplied him with a home and arranged that he attend school regularly during the winter months. Brant desires to send him to a Reserve school and, as he is not recognised as an Indian, this would be contrary to the policy of the Department in that none but Indian children are eligible to attend Indian Reserve schools. I would be pleased to receive the decision of the Department concerning this boy being allowed to attend a Reserve school. I am personally of the opinion that it would create a bad precedent and there are white tenants on the Reserve who would be seeking the same consideration and treatment for their children. Your early reply would be appreciated.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

ADM/JMcV
Ottawa, March 18, 1946.

Mr. A. D. Moore, Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 14th instant, the Department is not prepared to allow Francis Thompson to attend any of the schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve, as he is not an Indian.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention Welfare & Training Service.

In reply to your letter of August 14th, 1947, with reference to the possibility of transferring Mrs. Lena M. Elliott to the Sarnia School, I have approached Mrs. Elliott who has given me the enclosed letter to forward to you.

I might add that in view of the short time before school reopens, should Mrs. Elliott have transferred it would have put me in a most awkward position since there is one school on this reserve closed already because of the scarcity of teachers and I doubt, very much, if it would have been possible for me to obtain the services of another teacher to replace Mrs. Elliott before the Fall term. I trust that Mrs. Elliott's refusal will not affect her position as teacher of Mission School at this reserve.

N.C. Dimnell,
Clerk-in-Charge.
Mission School,
Shearonto, Ont.,
Aug. 18, 1947.

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Dept. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary,

Mr. Simmell has informed me of the vacancy in the Sarnia district and of the possibility of a transfer.

For the coming school year, I would hesitate to leave the Mission School as I have had a very difficult task of re-classifying and re-organizing here, also in getting the attendance up to normal. This work is not quite finished to my satisfaction.
Mission School,
Keeeronto, Ont.,
Aug. 18, 1947.

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary,

Mr. Simmell has informed me of the vacancy in the Sarnia district and of the possibility of a transfer.

For the coming school year, I would hesitate to leave the Mission School as I have had a very difficult task of re-classifying and re-organizing here, also in getting the attendance up to normal. This work is not quite finished to my satisfaction.
However, if, at some future date, a similar vacancy should arise, I should be pleased to hear from you.

I hope this decision will not cause you too much inconvenience in obtaining a teacher as the time for school opening is so near.

Yours very truly,

Lena M. Elliott

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Tyendinaga Central School
No. 441

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of Mrs. Ella Claus, teacher of the Tyendinaga Central School. She should be paid salary for the full month of April, but no further payment should be made to her.

To succeed her the Department has appointed Mrs. Eva Brant as teacher of this school for the months of May and June, 1943, at a salary of $85.00 a month, plus bonus. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the other forms will be forwarded to you when received.

Mrs. Brant is an Indian.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
July 30, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Tyendinaga Central Indian Day School, No. 441.

In my memorandum of April 19, I advised you of the appointment of Mrs. Eva Brant as teacher of this school for the months of May and June, 1943.

Mrs. Brant has now accepted the appointment at this school for the academic year 1943-44 and salary should be paid to her at the rate of $85.00 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective September 1, 1943. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and, as she has already supplied the forms required, new ones will not be necessary.

Mrs. Brant is an Indian.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

OTTAWA, July 20th, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the building of two new day school buildings on the Tyendinaga Reserve, one for the Western school and the other for the Central school.

In reply I beg to say that we have an extensive building programme on hand but, as soon as our Architect can prepare the plans, tenders will be called for.

It will be necessary to obtain another site for the Central school. It is not possible at the present time for an officer of this Department to visit the Reserve and select a suitable site. You and the members of the Council should be able to arrange this matter, which should receive your early attention. The site chosen should be central to the majority of the children who would attend, and should be dry and have good drainage facilities. There should be sufficient ground to provide ample playground, and, if necessary, a school garden.

It is not likely that the new buildings will be ready for occupation before the beginning of the new year.

You should take immediate steps to secure a site for the Central school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
for Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Fair Wages Clause.

All mechanics, labourers, or other persons who perform labour in the construction of the work hereby contracted for, shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed, and if there be no current rate in such district, then a fair and reasonable rate, and shall work such hours as those fixed by the custom of the trade in district where the work is carried on, or if there be no custom of the trade as respects hours in the district, then fair and reasonable hours, except for the protection of life and property, or on due cause shown to the satisfaction of the Minister of Labour. In the event of a dispute arising as to what is the current or a fair and reasonable rate of wages or what are the current hours fixed by the custom of the trade or fair and reasonable hours, it shall be determined by the Minister of Labour, whose decision shall be final. Payment may also be withheld of any money which would otherwise be payable to the contractor until the Minister of Labour's decision has been complied with. By the term "current wages" and the term "hours of labour fixed by the custom of the trade" in the foregoing are meant respectively the standard rates of wages and hours of labour either recognized by signed agreements between employers and workmen in the district from which the labour required is necessarily drawn or rates actually prevailing, although not necessarily recognized by signed agreements.

To accept tender for construction of two new school houses on the Tyendinaga Indian reserve.

There are four Indian day schools on this reserve. Two of them - known as the Central and the Western - have so deteriorated that money spent on repairs would be wasted.

Plans and specifications were sent to the Indian Agent on the 11th ultimo and he was requested to obtain competitive prices locally and submit them to the Department. Fastening of Wood and Iron

By Means of Our Combined Double Wedge and Dove-Tail Fastener

The accompanying cut plainly shows our exclusive method of fastening woodwork to iron. B represents upright standard. A represents the double wedge and dovetail, which slips into hole D in groove C of woodwork. When the wood is placed over the iron, wedge A fitting into hole D, and the back is driven downward, the wedge A forces the flange on standard firmly into the recessed groove C in woodwork, thus forming one continuous fastening the whole length of the wood.

Purchasing Commission of Canada.

Prices have been received for the supplying of a quantity of single school desks, and front and rear seats required for delivery at Deseronto, Ont., for the use of a new school building at the Central school on the Tyendinaga Reserve. Dear Sir,

Could you arrange to have benches built around the walls of the cloak rooms in the new school? They would be a great convenience. In the first place, the class room is small and the cloak rooms would be of more use if the benches were there. The children would have some place to sit while removing and putting on their rubbers. Also they could eat their lunch there thus keeping crumbs out of the class room. On stormy days, when the attendance is usually small, they could be used at recess and noon when playing games. Mr. Walker informs me that the cost would be $4.50 including everything for all the benches we require.

Also, the hall of the new school is absolutely dark, which is no doubt an oversight. Mr. Walker tells me this could be remedied by removing two of the panels and putting in glass. Something should be done about this soon.
matter, as this is not merely an inconvenience, but a danger in a public school. Benches such as we would like, are in the cloak rooms of the Collegiate at Napans. The pupils found them very useful. We always ate our lunch there, in fact were not allowed to bring it into the class room.

Thanking you for giving these matters your attention,

Yours truly,
Mrs. Celia Field

You have a very nice little school here now and when completed will be much appreciated by the children.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON THE TYENDINAGA CENTRAL INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, JUNE 5, 1925.

There are not sufficient seats for the present registration.

Not sufficient drinking cups. A dozen are desired.

The seating is by single non-adjustable seats and is satisfactory, except that a few more are required of NO. 3 size.

Closets are in terrible condition. The girls can scarcely use their closet without being fouled and the boys' closet is all full and partially wrecked. These buildings are too far away from the school to be easily accessible in bad weather.

H. J. Clarke,
Insp.
Ottawa, June 12th, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Central School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, has drawn attention to the condition of the closets. He states that they are in a terrible condition, and cannot be used without the children being fouled.

You should take immediate steps to have these closets thoroughly cleaned and put in a good, sanitary condition. This matter should not have been delayed until the present conditions developed. It is considered that the teacher should have reported the matter to you if you did not notice the same on your visits to the school. You should see that the closets at all the schools are thoroughly cleaned before the schools reopen after the holidays.

The Inspector also states that there are not sufficient seats in the Central School for the number of pupils in attendance. He recommends that a few more of the No. 3 size be supplied. Please state whether there is accommodation for more desks, and, if so, state the number required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Extract from Report of Inspector Clarke on the Central Mohawk Indian Day School - dated June 8th, 1926.

Like those at the Western School, these closets are far too far from the school. June 30, 1926.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Gentlemen,

The toilets at this school are much too far from the building. Last winter two of the little girls had a narrow escape from death through being trapped there during a storm. It took the combined efforts of the teacher and the larger boys to get them back into the school. We are in a badly exposed position here. I would recommend that these buildings be moved much nearer to the back of the school, during the summer vacation.

The walls of the school room and cloak rooms are badly soiled. They should be cleaned and decorated before September. I would recommend a pale shade of green, or else cream.

Very truly yours,
(teacher) Mrs. Celia Fife.
Sir,

I am enclosing herewith quarterly report from the Central School and also Requestion for School Supplies also a letter from the Teacher Mrs. File in reference to the closets which I explained when I was at the Dept., and in reference to the walls being soiled she never called my attention to it. And as this is a new school the walls should not be soiled as the Writer School walls are clean and not soiled.

Mrs. File told me sometime ago that she was going to write the Dept. and see if her Husband could take this School as she would like to go to Ladies College and I have not heard anything about it since...and by any thing is done I would think it advise she be put any Dept. of Ind Affairs.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. File, teacher of the Central School on the Tyendinaga reserve, relative to the toilets and requesting that they be moved nearer to the school building.

In reply I beg to say it is noted from Mr. Inspector Clarke's report that the present situation of these toilets is about 50 paces from the school. It is considered that, for sanitary reasons, it would be unsatisfactory to have them located near the rear of the school building. It is thought that the older boys, in winter, could keep a path cleared. We note the Inspector recommends that these toilets should be thoroughly cleaned out. You should arrange to have this done during the present summer holidays. The Department is not prepared to authorize having them moved nearer the school. You will remember that this matter was discussed with you during your last visit to the Department.

Please report later regarding the condition of the walls of the school building and state whether you would recommend that they be redecorated before the school opens after the present holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Kindly give me information regarding the financial assistance we can expect from the Department to aid in furnishing the pupils of the Indian Day Schools with a hot lunch. We have been having hot lunches in our school since Christmas (Central Mohawk Day School Tyendinaga Reserve). Both parents and pupils are very enthusiastic over it and the experiment has been such a success that I feel that something should be done to establish it permanently.

The advantages are very evident. I have had practically one hundred per cent possible attendance since this was begun. An epidemic of chicken pox and whooping cough has kept some children at home, but every child who was able has come to school every day this winter. January usually marks the lowest...
our attendance here, and so,
if only for this reason, think
the scheme should be
put upon a proper working
basis.

This is my sixth year in
this school, and it is the
most successful year we
have had in that time.
One family in particular,
living three miles across
country, is attending school
in a body, missing only
one day, when it stormed
so hard that not a pupil
could venture out. These children
cannot get to school in the
spring when the water is
high, consequently they have
formerly missed school
from Christmas until Easter or
even later. They are a sickly
family, and their mother
says — and truthfully, I believe
— that they cannot stand it to
walk so far through the snow
and eat a cold lunch.

Not only this but I am
positive that I can already
notice a change for the better
in the health of the whole
school. Formerly, I compelled
them to play out of doors at
least part of the noon hour.
Now the school is deserted as
soon as the lunch is eaten. The cleaning committee, of course, remains, and everything is in order by 12:30 or 12:45 at the outside.

At present we are "carrying on" with borrowed equipment, most of it my personal property. We are using a portable oil stove, one burner which must be carried back and forth night and morning, as I use it in my room at my boarding place. I have loaned a few cooking utensils from my own home—most of the homes here are too poor to spare any. The children who could, have brought their own dishes. We have not enough when everyone is present, but we manage somehow—often it is a bit awkward. We had a concert before Christmas, and, at present, we are buying our supplies with the money. Not many of the people here are able to help financially during the winter.
Try to furnish cheap, wholesome food. Our milk we buy at five cents a quart. It is too cold for the children to carry it so far. We have such food as porridge (rolled oats), cream of wheat, cooked rice, vegetable soup, potato soup, cocoa, creamed potatoes, macaroni and tomatoes, etc. The children like anything and everything. We have used no canned goods as yet, with the exception of one can of tomatoes. Much of the food I prepare and cook partly at my boarding place. Last week, our lunches averaged two cents each.

I can obtain an oil stove for (two-burner) for twenty dollars, from Boyle and Son, Napans. We need some sort of cupboard or cabinet, cooking utensils and dishes. Fifty dollars would furnish everything, think although I cannot be certain. If I am given credit for that amount at one of the hardware stores in Deseronto I will be able to buy at least the necessary things. Two dollars
a week would furnish us with food, supplemented by what the children bring. It would be money well spent, for many of these children are under nourished—one family, in particular, is in a half starved condition.

Kindly tell me what help I can expect in this matter. The present arrangement is only temporary, but, imperfect as it is, it has had simply marvellous results. Many more advantages come to mind—the work done in cooking, sewing, cleaning, etc., for example. It must be made a permanent thing in some way. Will the Department place a certain sum at my disposal, and let me expend it here, or shall I send a list of necessary articles and have them sent to me?

Very truly yours,
(Mrs) Helga B. Tile
Teacher & Central Mohawk Day School, Grandin.
Ottawa, February 10, 1926.

Sir,

The Department has received a communication from Mrs. File, teacher of the Central School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, requesting that supplies be furnished for the purpose of serving a midday lunch to the pupils. She states that they have been serving a lunch since Christmas with excellent results and that, as a consequence, there has been a full attendance of the Indian children.

In this connection I would refer you to official letter of October 30th last, and your reply thereto of November 4th. In view of the teacher's report as to the benefits accruing from the serving of this lunch, it is considered that it would be in the interests of the children and the work at the school to supply the necessary equipment and food for the purpose until the end of April, next. The teacher requests that an oil stove (2-burner), a cupboard and utensils for preparing and serving the meal be supplied. She states that approximately $50 would cover the cost of what is required. You should, therefore, arrange at once to purchase an oil stove (2-burner), a small cupboard in which to store food and utensils and a small number of utensils and dishes for the serving of the meal. Please consult the teacher as to what is required and arrange for the purchase as soon as possible. We are informing her that you have received authority to make these purchases.

Relative to the items of food required for the lunch to supplement what the children bring from their homes, you may purchase a small quantity of rolled oats, rice, cocoa and a small quantity of other food supplies for the purpose. The teacher states that she has been obtaining milk at five cents a quart, and you may arrange for a small quantity of same to be delivered each day. The teacher should keep an accurate record of the milk supplied. She also states that an expenditure of $10 a week would provide all the necessary food supplies required.

It is expected that the preparation and serving of the meal will not interfere with the regular classroom work of the teacher. She should obtain the assistance of the older girls in the preparation and serving of same. As the serving of this lunch is in the nature of an experiment, and is to be continued until the end of April, next, the Department will await a full report of the success achieved. We are informing Mrs. File of the authority granted you to make the purchases stated above.

You should forward accounts, in duplicate, promptly verified, covering the cost of the food and utensils purchased.

Your obedient servant,

The teacher tells me that she reported the
condition of this furnace but that no action was taken.
Apparently the grates are broken for the coal is falling
into the ash box; the feed door has nothing to hold it
shut and gas escapes badly into the room; the check damper
in the pipe does not work properly. Why cannot these minor
matters be attended to at the proper time, and before the
fire is needed. To repair it now, unless we get some
warmer weather, the fires will have to be let out and the
school dismissed for a time. There was no need of this at
all.

Why was this water tank allowed to go for
five weeks in this filthy state? I cannot see why it was
allowed to get into this state at all.

There is a water tank but it is so filthy
that it has not been used since vacation.
Ottawa, October 30, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Central Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the furnace. He states that apparently the grates are broken, as the coal falls through into the ash box; the feed door has nothing to hold it shut and gas escapes badly into the room and that the check damper in the pipe does not work properly.

You should arrange to have any repairs required to this furnace carried out as soon as possible. If any new parts are required, you should arrange for the purchase and installation of same. After the work has been completed, you should furnish an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

I would point out that the condition of this furnace should have been drawn to the attention of the Department by yourself in due time to have it placed in good condition before it was required for use this fall.

The Inspector states that there is a water tank, but it is in a filthy condition and has not been used since the summer vacation. You should arrange to have this tank cleaned out and placed in a sanitary condition, and an account, in duplicate, should be forwarded in the usual manner covering the expense incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Central Indian Day School, states that the front fence requires some small repairs. He states that the fence is damaged by the boys in climbing same, which could be easily avoided. Please draw this matter to the attention of the teacher, and she should see that the pupils do not damage the fence. You should arrange to have any repairs required carried out.

The Inspector further states that the water tank is now out of commission and that an open pail is being used for drinking water, which is unsanitary and an excellent way to transmit any communicable diseases that may exist. A report regarding what work is required in having the tank placed in a satisfactory condition, and the cost of same, should be made by you at an early date.

The Inspector also states that when the coal was put in the bin whatever kindlings there were were buried by the coal and that there is no kindling to light the fires. He states that the old toilets are useless and the material might be used for kindling if the caretaker is given permission to use same. The department will leave this matter in your hands and, if you consider that these old closets should be removed, the material in them could be broken up and used for kindling wood. December 7th, 1929

SIR.

In reply to your letter of Nov 29th Re the Conditions at the Central School, in reference to the Fence in front of the school, I beg to say that I made an inspection and find some of the posts rotted off and some of the wires broken which has been caused by horses and cattle reaching over the fence to get grass. The fence is shabby and I would recommend a new fence in front the same as we put up at the Eastren school and a new small gate, as the present Style is very shakey and dangerous for the children going over the steps, the cost would be about the same os the Eastren school fence.

As to the water tank the old one is cracked and will not hold water, a new one would cost about $5.00.

As to the Kindling wood we have lots of kindling and one of the old closets has been taken down and the other will be taken away, as I gave it to All Ste Church.

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your Obedient Servant,

G. M. Campbell
Agent.
Ottawa, December 11th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, reporting on the condition of the fence in front of the Central School on the Tyendinaga Reserve and recommending that a new fence be erected. It is, no doubt, too late this present season to have this work carried out, but the Department would approve of having a new fence erected next Spring of the same style of fencing as was recently put up at the Eastern School and known as style "LP" lawn fencing, with the necessary gates, posts and scantling. Please bear this matter in mind and arrange as soon as conditions permit next Spring to have the new fence erected in front of this school.

Relative to the water tank or container, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a new tank of sufficient capacity to meet the requirements. While a serviceable tank should be supplied, the cost should be as reasonable as possible. After this tank has been delivered, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The disposition made by you of the old closets has been noted. You should see that the site on which they stood is properly filled in and levelled.

Your obedient servant,

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing reports of your inspection of the Indian day schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve during the month of November, last.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is pleased to note the work at each of the schools is progressing satisfactorily and that there is a fair attendance. It is also noted that there has been loss, by thieving, of textbooks, etc., from the Eastern and Central Schools. It is considered that this matter should be followed up, with a view, if possible, to ascertaining the culprit, and you should make full enquiry in order to prevent an occurrence. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of any new locks that are required for the doors of these schools, and you should see that these new locks are installed at an early date. The caretakers and teachers should keep a strict watch to prevent further loss and with a view to discovering who is entering the schools and taking the supplies.

After you have purchased the locks and when same have been installed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Toilets are out of doors; under separate roofs and conveniently placed. One of the draw boxes should be emptied at once.

While we have no water supply here, I am pleased to learn that your Mr. McCougan was at the school yesterday and practically promised the teacher that a well would be provided.

There is a nasty hole in the front stoop, large enough for child to get a foot through and, if they did, running out as they do, a leg would probably be broken. In fact, the whole stoop should be rebuilt for it is all pretty well rotted out.
Ottawa, June 14, 1932.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Central Indian Day School, recommends that the draw boxes in the toilets be emptied at once. I have to request that you will arrange to have the toilets at all the schools cleaned out and placed in a good, sanitary condition immediately after the schools close for the coming summer holidays. Ottawa, June 16th, 1932.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Tyendinaga Agency on the 30th and 31st ultimo.

SCHOOLS

There are four Indian Day schools in the agency with a total roll of 157. On the day of my visit there were 137 pupils present. The register shows a very satisfactory average attendance. The pupils are reported as making excellent progress. Discipline in the different schools is good and the deportment of the pupils shows the results of the interest taken in them by their teachers. Besides the regular curriculum they are taught the rudiments of agriculture, sewing, knitting and mending. The classrooms are well equipped and on the whole clean and well ventilated. The outside closets are not cleaned out often enough. They should be cleaned once a month during the summer months and treated with lime to prevent odor. This applies to all four schools.

Thos. Mc Gookin,
Inspector.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Tyendinaga Agency on the 30th and 31st ultimo.

CENTRAL SCHOOL

In very fair condition. The interior needs redecorating. The classroom is dingy and depressing. There is no well here. The water has to be brought from a barnyard well about 40 rods from the school and has never been tested for drinking purposes. It is thought that water could be found on the school lot at very little expense for drilling. There are several drilled wells in the vicinity where water has been found at 50 feet.

Thos. Mc Gookin,
Inspector.
Ottawa, July 18, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Central School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, draws attention to the water supply. He states that the water used at the school has to be brought from a barnyard well about 40 rods from the school and that this water has never been tested for drinking purposes. He considers that water could be found on the school lot at very little expense for drilling, as there are several drilled wells in the vicinity where water has been found at 50¢.

I shall be pleased to have your report on the question of providing a water supply for this school. You should state whether you consider the water in the well from which the supply is obtained is pure and satisfactory in all respects for drinking purposes or whether you would recommend that a well be drilled on the school property. If the latter, you should state the approximate cost of drilling a well and installing a suitable pump. Please give this matter your prompt attention.

Sir:

Sir:

I beg to submit the following monthly report in connection with the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, for the month ending February 28th, 1935.

I have to report that some trouble is being experienced in connection with water supply at three of the schools on the reserve, the schools affected have no wells on the school properties but have to secure water from a distance, the schools concerned are the Central, Western and Mission. The Mission school in particular is very much handicapped more especially during the winter months. Water for this school has to be drawn from a distance of approx. two miles. Mr. T. Emmons, the teacher, draws the water using his car to do so. He finds it very hard during the winter months to make the necessary trips owing to the bad condition of the roads. The Central school have to get water from a nearby farm. The well of this farm is in the barnyard and the water is not very good owing to seepage of surface water. The Western school secure water from a creek which although it is running water is not strictly pure owing to the fact that the creek runs through farm lands and cattle and other animals use the stream. I would suggest that in order to overcome this shortage of water and to avoid any possible chance of contamination that as soon as possible wells be made on each of the school properties.

H. J. Eade,
Indian Agent.

I have to report further and advise that I communicated with Mr Gartley and informed him that he could proceed with the work at the above mentioned prices. Also that in the event that water is not found after drilling a reasonable depth, he would expect to be paid at the same rate as if water were found. I may say that it is customary in drilling wells for the driller to charge a certain price per foot, whether water is found or not, if water is not found, or if the water is found and turns out to be mineral or unfit for use, it is usual to try again at a reduced price on some other location on the property.

Mr Gartley before proceeding with the work would like to have definite assurance from the Department that if it is found necessary to go to a greater depth than that mentioned in the quotation, that he will receive additional pay at the rate mentioned, and also that in the event of water not being found that he will receive payment for his work at the rate mentioned namely $1.50 per foot.

Dear Sirs:— I understand that the representative of a Company selling Indoor Sanitary Toilets, has waited upon your Agent at Deseronto with the object of interesting him and through him, your Department in equipping the Mohawk Schools in Tyendinaga with this accommodation.

Let me premise what I am about to say with the statement that I am not in any way attempting to promote the sale of any particular style of Toilet. I have no interest financially in any company selling any school equipment. But I am deeply interested in the children that it is my privilege to meet from time to time as their Public School Inspector. I have visited your schools officially now for twenty-eight years, and they are as much to me as are the Public Schools under my inspection. Hence I am very desirous of seeing them have the advantage of modern sanitary accommodations. As I see it, it would be an excellent object lesson to these people of what should be. It is next to impossible to make children, particularly boys, take any care of the ordinary school outdoor toilets. Your children are no worse than others, but I have visited these schools when the toilets were an abomination. I have had frequent complaints from the teacher at the Eastern School, that tourists use the toilets after school hours, and foul them on occasion to a disgraceful state. It does not seem possible to keep them out. The schools off the Provincial Highway do not suffer to the same extent. I have been able of late to report the toilets as "reasonably clean."

Poor Copy
with the exception of eight, are equipped with indoor sanitary toilets, and I would very much like to see your schools equipped similarly.

I suppose that financial considerations have to enter into the matter at these times, but if the finances of the Department will stand the expense, in my opinion it would be a good investment to make, from the point of view of elevating the Indian, as well as promoting the health of the school girls who are approaching womanhood, and have to use in cold weather, the out-of-doors toilets. Of course they have to use them at home, and they always will unless they are shown the advantages of something better.

The representative referred to in the beginning of this letter called on me today, and told me that Mr. Eade would welcome my support in this matter. Hence this letter.

I would just like to say at this point, that while I have not had the privilege of meeting Mr. Eade since he became your Agent at Deseronto, I would like to say how much I appreciate the interest he is taking in these schools. In the past, I have had to advocate desired improvements, alone or almost alone. He sees the needs and is willing to co-operate in securing them. I feel that it is only simple justice to him, to say this, for I firmly believe that he is endeavouring to be a real agent.

Yours respectfully

H.J. Clarke
P.S. Inspector
Ottawa, January 11, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the installation of indoor sanitary toilets at the Tyendinaga Indian day schools.

It is agreed that this would be a very desirable improvement, but, owing to lack of funds, the Department is unable to favourably consider the matter at the present time.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

H. J. Clarke, Esq.,
Public School Inspector,
Belleville, Ont.

FORM No. 506
Sir,

I beg to ask authority to incur an expenditure during the balance of the current academic year the sum of $25.00 for the purpose of supplying hot lunches to the Indian pupils of three of the Tyendinaga Indian Day Schools.

In past years lunches were only supplied to pupils of the Eastern and Central Day Schools because of the fact that the Western and Mission schools were not equipped to serve hot lunches. This year however the teacher of the Mission school Miss Lilian Brant can arrange to serve hot lunches to her pupils if given the material to do so, namely soups or cocoa and other necessities.

In making this request I have to state that many of the pupils attending these schools come from a long distance and carry their noonday meal with them; the cocoa or soup supplied hot at school is of great benefit to them.

The Secretary

Department of Mines and Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Your Obedient Servant

H.J. Eade
Indian Agent
Sir,

I beg to request authority to expend the sum of $8.00 for the purpose of giving the pupils of the four Indian Day Schools on the Reserve an Xmas treat.

Many of the children attending the schools are from poor families and their parents are not in a position to give them xmas presents which children look forward to at Christmas time. If granted the money will be spent in such a way that each child will receive an equal share of fruit or candies which will be distributed under the supervision of the teachers of the four schools.

The Secretary

Department of Mines and Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Your Obedient Servant

H.J. Eade
Indian Agent
EX'D.

Ottawa, November 26, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letters of the 24th instant, you may expend an amount of $8.00 for the purpose of giving the pupils of the four Indian Day Schools on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve a Christmas treat.

You may also expend an amount of $25.00 in purchasing materials required to serve a hot lunch at the Eastern, Central and Mission Schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

H. J. Bade, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.
Sir,

I beg to refer you to my letter of the 24th ultimo and your reply of November 26th, file 43-1-5 dealing with an expenditure for the serving of Monday lunches at the Tyendinaga Eastern, Central and Mission day schools of the reserve.

I have to state that in my request for authority I asked for the sum of $25.00 for the purpose of supplying lunches to the pupils of the three schools during the balance of the academic year. In making the request in that way I made a mistake. What I intended to request was that $25.00 per month be allowed for the purpose of supplying lunches. Last year the amount per month allowed by the Department was $20.00 but this year the teacher of the Mission school is willing to look after the lunch for her pupils if the Department will approve of the extra sum involved.

Will you please write me and give your approval if possible, lunches will be served in the three schools during the months of December to April of the present academic year.

The Secretary

Indian Affairs Branch

Extract from Indian Agent Eade's letter of June 21, 1938:

Central School

New door required for main entrance, also door step renewed.
New screens required for windows.
New heater required for school, present heater in dangerous condition, fire pot badly cracked. Four new desks required, attendance increasing and not sufficient seating room.

In regard to the new heater required for the Central School, I beg to state that the present heater was purchased from the James Stewart Manufacturing Co., Woodstock, Ont. Name of heater, Good Cheer, No. 520. This heater has always given satisfaction and is a suitable type of heater for this school.

In regard to the new desks required, single seats are preferable, the present seats in the school are Style 3 supplied by A.S.K. Co. School Furniture Co., Preston, Ont.

(Sgd.) H. J. Eade,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 24, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of June 21
the Department approves the following repairs at the
Tyendinaga Central School:

New door for main entrance.
New door step.
New screens for windows.

In connection with the above the same
instructions regarding material are in effect as
mentioned in my letter of concurrent date in connection
with the Tyendinaga Eastern School.

You might let me know the approximate cost
of the heater which you consider necessary for this
school. Was the similar heater that was formerly
purchased secured locally or was it bought direct
from the manufacturer?

I am requesting the Purchasing Agent to secure
the 4 new desks. These will be shipped to you at
Deseronto and the account covering their cost will also
be forwarded to you. On receipt of the desks you should
certify the account and forward it to the Department for
payment.

Yours truly,

H. J. Eade, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to a new heater which you state is necessary at the Tyendinaga Central Day School.

**DATE:** Jan 6/39
Sir:

I beg to submit the following monthly report in connection with Tyendinaga Indian Agency for the month ending December 31st, 1938.

SCHOOLS

The school attendance during the month has I believe improved, every effort is being made to get the children out more regular, all schools closed for the Christmas Holidays on Dec. 21st, each school putting on a Christmas concert for the benefit of the parents. A Christmas treat was given to each pupil, supplied by the Department, and the children spent a happy time.

Noonday lunches are now being served in the schools, and it is a great benefit to the children who are unable to return home for noonday lunch, owing to the distance some of them live from the school. Cod Liver oil is also being given once a day to each pupil in all schools, this is found to be very beneficial and helps to build the children up and ward off colds. The children are all well clothed and the schools are kept warm and comfortable.

H. J. Eade,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to bring to your attention the following extracts from Inspector Clarke's reports regarding his recent inspection of the four schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve:

CENTRAL

Toilets are apparently not swept. Boxes should be emptied before they become the breeding place for millions of flies.

MISSION

Toilets are poor affairs, particularly the boys'. The draw-box is not properly placed, and the interior of the box so light that it will soon be the breeding place of millions of flies. You have no screen door, and one window is unscreened.

EASTERN

Toilets require repairs, particularly the boys'. The three entrances are out of repair. The flooring at the main entrance is so badly decayed that someone is liable to break through and suffer a serious injury.

WESTERN

Toilet boxes should be emptied at once. They are nearly filled. The space for the boxes should be darkened, so as to exclude flies or they will breed by millions in the filth. At present the interior of the boxes is about as light as if they were out in the open.

M.W. McCracken, Esq.,
In Charge Tyendinaga Indian Agency,
Deseronto, Ont.
WESTERN (Cont'd)

The fences are out of repair. Horses have been on the yard and when they went out, they took the front gate and post with them. The children are attempting to have flower beds, but what is the use unless the fences are repaired?

The above-mentioned matters should receive immediate attention, particularly the cleaning of the toilets.

For your information I may add that in the current year's appropriation an amount of $350.00 was provided for general repairs and painting at the four schools in the Tyendinaga Agency. It would be appreciated if you would let me know in what manner you consider the above amount should be expended. In the event of any material being required full particulars should be given in order that purchase can be made by our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 24-1-5 of June 16th with reference to Inspector Clarke's reports concerning the four Indian Day Schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve and would beg to submit a report on the general repairs which are considered necessary at each of the following schools.

**Eastern School**

One side of school roof leaks and should be patched with shingles.

Repairs to floors at main entrance as well as boys' and girls' entrances as floor boards and posts have become rotten and broken in some places.

Both boys' and girls' toilets require shingles on roofs.

A new door is needed in boys' toilet.

Repair broken and missing boards in screens around toilets and replacing of a rotted post at one end of girls' screen.

New seat needed in boys' toilet.

Windows in three entrances to school need reputting.

Repair to broken lattice work on girls' entrance.

The total cost of material and labour for the above mentioned repairs considered necessary at the Eastern School is estimated at $35.00.

**Central School**

A new fence should be erected on three sides of this school as the old fence on the east, west and north sides is in very poor condition. A total of 35 rods of ordinary galvanized woven wire fence is needed to prevent damage by cattle to the school property.

Two loads of gravel placed around the front entrance would help fill the large hollow and assist in eliminating water and mud which surrounds entrance in wet weather.

Minor repairs to toilets is also thought necessary.

The total cost for material and labour for fencing, gravel and repairs is estimated at $40.00.
Mission School

1 screen door required for front entrance.
1 screen for window.
A new shingle roof is necessary on boys' toilet, also new flooring and repairs to screens.
Toilet boxes need adjustment and new gate at rear to help darken the interior.

Estimated cost of material and labour for above repairs is estimated to be $20.00.

Western School

A new fence around this school property is badly needed. I consider an ordinary woven wire fence would be suitable and would cost approximately $50.00 for material and labour.

Boards are missing and broken in both toilets and if these were repaired the interior would be darkened. Bracing of posts and boards on screens are necessary which would cost in the vicinity of $10.00 for material and labour and this would greatly improve these toilets.

I would recommend that authority be granted to have this repair work done as outlined above for each of these four schools. Indian carpenters would be engaged to do the carpentry work and Indian labour on the fencing to be done would be used. The unexpended balance of the $350.00 available would be ascertained when this work has been completed and could then be used in painting the Eastern School or any one of the other schools as they are all badly in need of painting.

In connection with Inspector Clarke's recommendations concerning the emptying of the toilets at the Central School, I would advise that these were not more than one-quarter full on date of my visit. However, the toilets at the Western School do need emptying. This work at each of the four schools will be attended to in the very near future.

Your obedient servant,

AGENT'S REPORT ON TYENDINAGA AGENCY FOR JULY 1939.

The four Indian day schools have been closed during the month of July for the summer holiday period. General repair work found necessary at these schools is being done by Indian labour. It was impossible to secure an Indian carpenter in July to do carpentry work at the schools due to the fact that all Indian carpenters were employed in the construction of the storage granary. This caused delay in having repair work done on the schools but repairing has now been started and should be completed by the end of next week. After the repair work on the schools is completed, it is thought that there will be some unexpended funds from the $350.00 which was set aside by the Department for school repairs at this agency and if so, it is suggested that one or two of the schools be painted this year. However, the unexpended balance cannot be ascertained until the repair work has been finished. A letter in connection with the painting of the schools will be forwarded to the department at a later date.

M. W. McCracken,
In Charge.
Deseronto, Ontario.
August 12th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Under Departmental letters of June 30th, files 34-1-5, 34-2-5, 34-3-5, 34-4-5, authorization was granted to have certain repair work done at each of the four Indian Day Schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve. This work is being carried out in accordance with instructions. Due to the fact that all Indian carpenters were engaged in working on the storage granary during June and July, it was not possible to commence the school work until this month as an Indian carpenter could not be secured. This caused delay in completing the repairs to the schools but it is expected that the repairs will be completed by the end of next week. When work on repairing the entrances etc. was started, it was found that other repairs which were not included in the original estimate would be necessary. Due to this, the estimate of money to be expended for these repairs may be slightly exceeded. The accounts which will include cost of material and labour for fencing and general repair work at these schools will be forwarded when the work is completed next week.

After the work which has already been authorized on these schools is completed, it is almost certain that there will be a considerable unexpended balance remaining from the $350.00 available for Tyendinaga schools this year. As the Department are no doubt aware, each one of the four schools needs painting badly. In view of the fact that the Eastern School is on the Ontario Provincial Highway, I would suggest that it be painted first at an estimated cost for material and labour of $75.00. If the unexpended balance is still sufficient after the Eastern School has been painted, I would recommend painting the Western School at approximately the same cost as the Eastern. A competent Indian painter is available to do this work which should be commenced immediately so that it would be finished before school opens in September.

I would wish to be advised if it meets with the approval of the Department to paint the Eastern School. After this has been done, the amount of funds still available could be determined and if sufficient, the Western School could then be painted.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

AGENT'S REPORT ON TYENDINAGA RESERVE FOR SEPT. 1939.

A wind and hail storm of cyclonic proportions visited this agency on September 8th with the result that twelve barns on the reserve were completely destroyed. The roof on the All Saint's Church on this reserve was completely torn off. A large steeple crashed through the roof of the Christ's Church. Chimneys on the Council Hall were blown down and many small buildings and parts of roofs, garages, etc. were demolished throughout the reserve. In view of the extensive damage done to the Churches which are band property and would therefore have to be repaired from funds of the Band, I did notify the Department immediately after the storm and Mr. Patrick did visit this agency to inspect the damage.

A small portion of the shingle roof was torn off the Western school and numerous panes of glass were broken in each of the four Indian Day schools. Repairs at the schools were considered urgent and have been completed. Instructions are being awaited from the Department in connection with repair work necessary at the two Churches and in the meantime I authorized Rev. Pringle to conduct Church services in the two Day Schools on this reserve.

M.W. McCracken,
In Charge.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant regarding Christmas treats for the children of the Tyendinaga schools I would refer you to official letter of December 6, 1939, in which the former Agent was advised that the Department did not intend to make any grants for this purpose after the year 1939.

It is considered that the teacher should be able to arrange a concert a week or so before Christmas and either charge a small admission fee or take up a collection. Dear Sir:

Some considerable repairs are needed at the Central Day school the most necessary need being the painting of the class-room and interior to improve the lighting, which is quite bad due to the ceiling of the school being of T & G lumber darkly varnished making it necessary on dull days for the teacher to move all her pupils adjacent to the windows to see to do their work. This ceiling should have three coats of white or light ivory paint and the wall which are of plaster should have two coats of ivory after some small repairs have been made to cracked and loose plaster. The main-scoting in the class-room as well as all interior woodwork should be cleaned and given another coat of varnish in an endeavor to brighten it up.

While an expensive wood was used in the finish in this school it was to light and every door in the school is loose, due to the frames cracking and splitting and not being of a substantial wood to hold nails and screws and it will be necessary to replace a portion of each of these door frames. The same conditions exists in the cloak rooms where this fine lumber is full of holes and split from screws from coat hangers, all of which hangers are now off the walls. These boards should also be replaced by heavier and harder wood.

A new front door 36" X 7' X 1\(\frac{1}{4}\)" with 6 small panes is also needed as the present door is quite the worse for wear and has been repaired many times.

In addition the following small repairs are needed at this school,

- A small toolshed for storing windows, screens, garden tools, etc., 4' X 4' X 7' high of matched lumber to be erected behind the coal shed on the north side.
- Repair screens, doors and boxes at the school outhouses.
- Re-nail wire fencing to posts and install 2 pieces of 2 X 4 in same.
- Make urinal trough in boys outhouse.
- Repair locks or replace same on two doors in class-room.
- Repair protective screen around stove in class-room.
- Install new sill at front door of school.
- Floor school porch with 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch flooring, size 5' X 6'.
- Repair and tighten down some class-room desks.
- Procure and install 80 feet of savetroughing, 20 feet of conductor pipe and four elbows to replace present pipe which is rotten and useless and is allowing water to damage the foundation of the school.

The cost of the materials necessary to make these repairs should not exceed $85.00 and the cost of the labour $60.00 and it is requested that authority be granted to procure the necessary materials and that an advance be made for wages to be accounted for by credit voucher.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,
A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

OCT 17 1942 Deseronto, Ont. October 15th 1942.

Dear Sir:

Tyendinaga School Improvement Competition.

A competition was held this year for the improvement of the grounds at the four day schools on Tyendinaga Reserve and in May last an inspection was made of the schools and they were listed in accordance with their advanced state of improvement at that time and given the following classification; 1st Eastern; 2nd Mission; 3rd Central and 4th Western.

In the early Spring trees were procured from the Ontario Forestry Branch and shrubs from a nursery and were planted in accordance with the landscape plans provided by Mr. Chas. Buchanan of the Ontario Agricultural Department. Annual plants and flowers were also supplied and planted by the teachers and pupils of the schools.

On October 14th Mr. Buchanan did judge these school grounds to award prizes for the school showing the greatest improvement since his inspection of the grounds in May and the following was the result of such judging,

1st Central Day School, Prize $5.00
2nd Eastern Day School, " 3.00
3rd Western Day School, " 2.00
4th Mission Day School. Painting.

The prizes were given through local contributions and have been an incentive to make this competition a success and Mr. Buchanan states that he finds a greater improvement for the year at the reserve schools than was found in all the schools of the Counties of Lennox and Addington, which are his charge.

Garden tools, lawn mowers, etc., have been supplied the reserve schools and next Spring it is hoped to continue this improvement plan in planting more shrubs and nursery trees to make an advanced improvement to the schools of the Agency.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,
A. D. Moore, Indian Agent
Ottawa, October 19, 1942.

Re: Tyendinaga School Improvement Competition

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein.

It is to the officials here and to myself a great source of satisfaction and encouragement to learn of the attempts that have been made to improve and beautify school grounds on the Tyendinaga reserve. It is difficult to over-emphasize the effect of neat and well kept school grounds on the minds of growing pupils.

We note from the information contained in the last paragraph of your communication that it is your intention to continue and to extend this work during the spring and summer season. It is our intention to send forward a summary of your letter to the Director for his information. A summary will also be sent forward to the Minister's office.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

January 4th 1945.

Secretary,

EDUCATION:

The attendance at the day schools has not been good and part of this can be attributed to severe colds, the balance to the lack of co-operation by the parents in sending their children regularly. The weather during December has been very severe and this has attributed some to the poor attendance. Mission School was closed for nine days during the month on account of the teacher being ill. Manual training materials have not as yet been supplied the school and we are waiting the decision of the Fair Board as to whether they intend holding a fair next year and providing prize money for school exhibits, as this materials is secured to make products that are listed for prizes in the school exhibits. The board are late in making their decision, which is expected during the month of January.

A.D. Moore,

REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1946.

Schools:

The attendance at the schools has been quite good and during the latter part of the month, a considerable number of the elder pupils were kept from school to assist their parents on their farms in planting spring grain and canning crops. Public School Inspector Birkin, Napanee, Ont., made his official visit to the schools on May 22nd and 23rd, there being a very good attendance at Central and Western and only a fair turnout at Mission and Eastern Schools. I visited these schools at the time of Mr. Birkin's inspection and this official seemed well satisfied with the progress of the pupils and the services of the teachers and spoke highly of the vocational program being carried out. Suggestions were made in connection with some minor repairs, a report of which will be made after my June visit to the schools, so that the work can be done during the vacation period. Mr. Birkin seems favourable to a consolidated school project on the Tyendinaga Reserves, as some progress has been made in this in his inspectorate of the Counties Lennox and Addington with marked success in administration and equipment and accommodation at rural schools.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

SCHOOLS:

There are four schools on the Reserve one of which, the Western School, is closed and children from this vicinity are attending Shannonville Public School.

The Eastern School, under Miss Stothard, has thirty-one pupils at the present time. The school is in pretty fair condition, but the toilet facilities are about falling apart. It should be replaced entirely and I would suggest the location be moved down the hill behind the school where they will not be so conspicuous.

Central School, under Mr. Claus, has a very small attendance - about sixteen pupils. The building is in good condition except for the odd minor repair and some paint.
Deseronto, Ont.
July 30th, 1948

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to the Day Schools on Tyendinaga Reserve, it is submitted that since it is improbable that further action with regards to a two room school will be taken before the Fall term commences, it will be necessary to effect certain necessary repairs to the present schools.

It is therefore requested that the sum of $500.00 be forwarded to this Office to pay for these minor repairs, lumber and materials, so that the necessary repairs may be effected at an early date.

In so far as materials are concerned, they will only be in the nature of small quantities of screening, paint and lumber, which should not total more than $100.00 and it is therefore requested that permission be granted to purchase any materials locally rather than through the purchasing agent, so as to avoid any unnecessary delay since exact quantities are not known.

Could I be advised of any further information you require at your earliest opportunity, please.

Yours truly,

N.C. Dimmell,
for Indian Agent.
