Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Tyendinaga Indian Day Schools.

As you are probably aware, there are several trips which I have delayed now for the past eight months and some of them present matters which will have to be settled in the near future if we are not to delay our building programme.

Mr. Morris has agreed to take me to Tyendinaga for next Monday and Tuesday. We have three Indian schools in operation there and one now vacant.

The rather serious problem now confronts us of either opening the old school again or arranging to transport these Indian children to the nearby Provincial School at Shannonville.

There are several complicated factors to be considered in making a decision. One of the most serious is the high cost of transportation.

There are twelve children from this reserve now attending high school and seven at the Belleville Collegiate.

I would appreciate receiving your approval for my visit to this reserve for Monday, May 16, and Tuesday, May 17.

I would also welcome an opportunity of discussing with you the proposed inspection trip of the schools in the Port Arthur Agency, which I mentioned to you previously.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
RELATING TO EDUCATIONAL MATTERS ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN RESERVE

(1) Primary Education: There are approximately 145 pupils now attending Elementary Schools, 100 of these are attending our three schools on the Reserve, and 45 are going to schools outside the Reserve. Of the 100, approximately 50 are attending Eastern Day School, 32 Mission Day School and 18 Central Day School. Of the 45 pupils attending outside Schools, 2 are at Deseronto Public School, 31 at Shannonville, 12 at Milltown Public School, the others attend Deseronto High School and Belleville Collegiate. Besides the Indian Pupils there are a number of white children resident on leased land on the reserve, who at present are not eligible to attend Indian Schools.

We have at present 3 Indian Schools in operation and one vacant. Eastern Day School is situated on No. 2 Highway, Lot 32, Con. A. This is a fine frame school in a good state of repair. It has a good basement used for teaching Home Economics and Shop and quite a large play ground. At present it is vastly overcrowded because the population seems to have shifted to the east end of the reserve.

Mission School, is located on Lot 27, Con.2, is a frame structure which has been in use for quite a long time. Although there has been a number of complaints from the Teacher that the building is done, I cannot say that I have any evidence to substantiate these claims. The building is certainly not as well kept as the Eastern School, nor are the grounds in as good shape. There is a separated teacherage at this school, which is in a good state of repair.

Central School, also a frame structure is in good state of repair and has a fine set of grounds. It is located on Lot 21, Con. A. and as its name would indicate is central on the reserve.

Western, our fourth school building, is located on Lot 10, Con.2. I did inspect this building and find that with very little cleaning and redecorating it will be quite suitable to put into use again. I understand it was closed a few years back when the school population decreased. However there are sufficient now to make a good school (see map). I therefore recommend that this school be put into shape for the next Fall Term.

There may be need also for another School building to relieve the congestion at Eastern School. I am not prepared to suggest a site at the present time for this new building, but I am of the opinion that it should be located somewhere south and west of Eastern School. I shall enclose with this report a map locating all the pupils on the reserve, from which you may be able to determine a suitable location before visiting the reserve.

The suggestion has been put forward that one central graded school would be advisable for this reserve and then transport the pupils to it by bus. While this plan may have many advantages in so far as better education is concerned I do see the following objections:

If we hired the transportation it would cost approximately $90.00 per pupil per year. This added cost would not be offset by any saving in teachers or any greater economy of operation costs. Also the time the pupils would be away from home would be greatly increased on the average due to the loop method used by school buses. This added time is generally taken from the children's "free" time as the same chores still have to be done at home. We would also be using a great amount of money for a new school building to replace our four good schools buildings.

At the present time we have 3 teachers on the reserve; Miss Stoddart, I find quite capable and doing an excellent job at Eastern School. She lives in the Town of Deseronto and commutes night and morning.

Mrs Elliott lives with her husband in the Teacherage at Mission School. She has lived on the reserve practically all her life and so has become quite an influence.

Mr Claus is an Indian on the Reserve and has been teaching at Central School. I am of the opinion that he will resign this year and take up carpentry and farming, for which I feel he is well suited.
I do feel that our teachers might give more leadership in their communities to encourage the children in extra curricular activities. Having taught myself, for some years, I understand the objections the teachers will raise to this suggestion, but I repeat that I expect teachers to give some leadership in the community. I have been able to hold a Staff meeting a month and am of the opinion that this is a good policy, as teachers and I are able to exchange ideas and settle a number of problems.

In so far as the curriculum used on this reserve is concerned I believe it to be on the whole satisfactory. However, in view of the fact that our High School pupils number somewhat less than 9% of Public School enrolment, it would seem that our Public School curriculum must fit the children for life. I would therefore suggest introduction of some more practical subjects. Home Economics at present is taught in only one school, as is crafts (to any extent). Also we have little instruction in music, which is a poor policy, because these Indians have great natural musical abilities. The difficulty to introducing these courses is in obtaining competent teachers. It may be possible to co-operate with schools outside the reserve and make use of itinerant teachers, particularly for music. I recommend that this suggestion be given due consideration.

**SECONDARY EDUCATION**: At present we have 12 pupils from the reserve attending Secondary Schools, 5 at Deseronto High School and 7 at Belleville Collegiate and Vocational School. Notwithstanding this paucity of Secondary pupils the level of achievement of these pupils is very low, so low that I am inclined to think that our children are building up a reputation for poor scholarship for the Indians. Of course there are a few exceptions. I am at a loss to get a full explanation of this situation, but one reason might be put forward, that is the home background which is not encouraging; another sometimes suggested is the scarcity of openings for trained Indians resulting in little incentive for scholars. Apparently the inherent reticence of the Indian has also probably discouraged a number from taking higher education.

**Other Training**: At present we have only one girl attending an institution other than high or public school. There just doesn't seem to be any incentive or interest in further training when the pupils reach the age of 16 or 18. However I have had a number of older men and women express regret that they had not proceeded further with their education. If these expressions are sincere it might be possible to introduce short courses during the off seasons. One which has already been suggested is "farm wiring" (in view of the fact that we are expecting to get the reserve wired next year). The Ontario Government sponsors a series of these courses locally and we may be able to make use of their organization next winter.
Deseronto, Ont.

Sir,

On the 7th May last I visited and examined school No. 1 on Wolfe Island conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, and taught by Albert Sahgy, a young Indian, who has passed the Entrance High School examination. The school is situated on the west side of the island and is fairly centrally situated. The building is about 20 x 26 feet and is in good condition, and the grounds, about 100 x 120 feet, are fenced and kept in good order. The outbuildings are in good condition. There was a supply of about 5 cords of wood piled up in the yard. The seats are old bench seats, taken, I think, from an old church which has been replaced by a new church, and give seating capacity for 32 pupils. The stove and fuses are in fair condition. There is a fair blackboard, globe, map of the older provinces of the Dominion, and a map of the world. The teacher requires the first part of the First Book in the form of tablet lessons. There were 35 pupils present on the day of my visitation, 22 boys and 13 girls. The order was good, and the teacher evidently has good control of the school.

Sir,

OTTAWA, 2nd November, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent McDougall forwards a resolution of the Council of the Chippewas and Pottawatomies of Walpole Island against the establishment of a central school as suggested by Mr Inspector Mosher. The Agent states that the Indians think that if a central school were built to take the place of the three now in operation on the Island, that Indian teachers would be removed and replaced by whites.

Judging by the Inspector's reports on these schools such a change appears to be most desirable as none of the Indian teachers have had any training and hold only Entrance Examination certificates.

There are about 160 children of school age on the Island and very few of them are benefited to any extent by the present schools owing to the indifference of their parents in regard to education. The salaries of these schools aggregate $800.00, of which $500.00 is paid by the Band and the total annual cost of the schools is little short of $1000.00 a year for repairs, etc. If a graded school were built on the reserve in a central location a better average attendance than the three schools at present have could be secured and better results obtained at less cost. The Indians are quite well able to pay for a
modern school building and the salaries of two duly qualified white teachers. I do not see that their anxiety to retain the services of incompetent Indian teachers should be allowed to interfere with the proper education of their children.

I would suggest that Mr Agent McDougall be advised that unless the present teachers can obtain district certificates before the re-opening of the schools next year, that they should not be re-engaged. A good many of the older children from the Island attend the Industrial schools at Sault Ste Marie and Mt. Elgin, but that is no reason why the younger ones should not receive a good elementary education.

Her non-professional standing is better than that of the ordinary candidate for a District Certificate as she tried last July for the Junior Teacher non-professional standing, and failed only in Physics and Latin. Her education and training is, therefore, all that you require.

If she proves to be able to govern well (and that cannot be told until she is tested in her own school) she should give good satisfaction. I think she would do better in number three school on the east side of the island (closed this term) than she would in No. 1 school where there are some large boys who may be a little hard to control. If, however, no better one applies for No. 1 she should do better work than is now being done in it, and Miss Aylesworth, now in number 1 could be transferred to No. 3 which is much smaller than No. 1, easier to manage, and only a few rods from her father's home.

Truly Yours,

D. D. Mosher

P.S. Inspector.

Will you please allow me to make a brief explanation of the same? I live in Algoma and cannot get the ferry to cross the river early enough in the morning.

Ottawa, November 19th, 1909.

Sir,

As you have some interest in Miss Bessie Cameron, Teacher of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island, I have to inform you that the Department regrets that it would be unfair to all concerned if she were continued in the position after the close of the present year.

As you were informed on the 28th of July, 1906, Miss Cameron's appointment was to depend upon the success with which she conducted the school. Since she entered upon her duties the Department has received three reports from the Public School Inspector for that district, all of which go to show that Miss Cameron is not giving satisfaction.

The Inspector states that "Miss Cameron claims to have an expired Third Class certificate, but is not able to produce it. She had six months' experience before assuming charge of this school, but as she is at least sixty years old that experience was gained some forty years ago. The Inspector further states that Miss Cameron does not know how to teach and is too old to learn, and that steps should be taken to provide an efficient teacher, otherwise it would be almost as well to close the school."

You will see from the foregoing extracts from the Inspector's report that there is no other course open to the Department than to ask for Miss Cameron's retirement at the end of the current quarter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, in which you state that you were leaving on that date for Walpole Island to take charge of the No. 1 School.

As you were advised on the 2nd instant your retention in this position will depend upon the success with which you meet. In addition to you work in the school-room it will be necessary for you to obtain the confidence and sympathy of the Indians. This can only be done by mingling with them freely in their homes. Indians as a rule are apathetic in their attitude towards the education of their children and the arousing of their interest is one of the essentials of success. As you are an experienced teacher it is not necessary to say anything in reference to ways and means of interesting the children in the work in the class-room.

The Department will await the result of your efforts, which it is hoped will be entirely satisfactory.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant in further reference to your work as teacher of the Walpole Island No. 1 school.

In reply I beg to say that the reports received upon your work up to the present time would not justify the Department in granting you any increase in salary; in fact, unless there is a decided improvement in your management, especially with regard to the cleanliness of the school-room and surroundings, it will be necessary to ask for your resignation.

The Department does not approve of your allowing the children to visit the stores and wharves at the noon hour. They should be constantly within your supervision from the time they arrive at the school in the morning until they leave again in the evening.

It is not considered necessary that you should have an agreement as the official correspondence which you have in your possession sets forth the terms upon which you were engaged and the Department reserves the right to dispense with your services upon giving you due notification.

Your obedient servant,

W. A. Batchelor, Esq.,
Teacher,
Walpole Island, Ont.

Sir,

They state that I have read the charges made against me as teacher of No. 1 School at Pelican Island by Agent McDougall. I shall endeavor to answer some of these and show that many of them are not true.

The agent was prejudiced against me and said once that I wished to complain him as agent. I had not the remotest idea of being Indian agent in any place.

Schools. Things in school and our event well until the Agent tried to injure me. I was told this by some. I supposed he circulated statements re my health etc.
School—During my term some 214 new pupils were added to the school. I had a true friend ship for the children and gave them plenty gifts.

After the Thomas children came to school there was some trouble with them. The children had the Western Echo. I sent them this to Agent McDougall but he took no action.

I am charged with assaulting one Clarence Thomas a pupil of the school. I gave the boy a whipping for being very noisy and rebellious in school and class.

It was shown in court that the boy had no marks on him.

Clarence was new scholar to me he had previously attended school in Michigan and he told me he was in trouble there, he said he drank whisky and did other bad things. In school I told him to say word or lesson he would yell quite loud at times.
He said he stayed out of school or run away while in Wabash. I would say that when I whipped Clarence he screamed loud and this caused some of the children to cry. I put them out of the school. I suppose the children were scared when the grown up Indians and white man were at door to assault me.

I think this assault was planned by a white man who rode about in a auto and I was told he did sell a good deal of liquor. He was not at the trial I suppose he ran away. The parties who assaulted me came from a house which was not a good. They were drunk the worse of liquor in the morning. I passed the white man in his auto and he stopped and was ready for fight. He is a stranger to this island I think.
This man in the auto used to drive at furious pace past the school and I spoke to him that it was not safe however I am sure that he was assisted by the Indians through matter.

Trial: Should have entered a charge of assault against the parties.

After a trial before a magistrate on Malpole Island, it seems some told the magistrate to send me to Jarvis to be tried by the judge and I was detained at Jarvis till the judge was ready. At the trial there was no proof of any marks by the boy. The judge had great difficulty in reading the statements by J.P. from the country. The judge did dispose of a fine of $10 but after further consideration he said there was no fine or costs as I was discharged.
Court. Inspector Conn stopped his work for the day and gave evidence stating that he had a good school and was well qualified man.

State of mind of teacher.

I did not drink or use narcotics, after pills now and then. I think the reason I was disliked by a few was because I did not smoke whisky in them. I have been often packed to do so.

At my boarding house I was very much annoyed by drunken Indians—white men. They did strike me but they were amiss.

The man of the house kept public dances in the house sometimes lasting 2 or 3 a.m. The children were very bad. No rules or government.
When the house was empty I took a walk out or sat in the school at 4 p.m.

Josephine Davis noticed and the Agent ought thinks I was silly.

I would walk along the shore river and study nature.

Sir:-

With reference to your letter of January 24th, 1911 File No-152941-1, I have the honour to report as follows:

I visited the No-1 school on Walpole Island on the morning of February 6th arriving at 9.20. There was just one scholar present three more came in within the next 10 minutes and two more shortly after that, making a total of 6 in attendance during that forenoon. I say say that it was a very stormy day which no doubt would account somewhat for the small attendance but strange to say all those that were present were small girls, no boys. The teacher Miss McDougall at this school claims no particular qualification for her position. She is a bright girl but does not take her duty seriously, as she considers that she is just merely filling in for the time being.

Since the 1st of January there have been only 17 scholars enrolled at this school where there should have been over 30. The attendance has ranged all the way from 1 to 11 scholars per day. There has been considerable sickness upon the island during the past month which accounts partially for the state of affairs. I am informed whoever that there are about 40 children of school age within the radius of this school, and I think with a good energetic teacher and cooperation of the parents, this should be one of our best Indian schools.

J. G. Ramsden

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your report of the 10th instant upon the No. 1 school on Walpole Island.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to learn that you found the school-room in good condition upon the occasion of your visit. I may say, however, that there is further information that the Department wishes to obtain if possible.

A Mr. Batchelor was in charge of this school for several months during the past year and his services were dispensed with upon complaints being made as to his management of the school and as to his personal conduct. I would ask whether during the time that you were on the reserve you learned anything with respect to Mr. Batchelor's work. At that time the building was reported to be in a poor condition in respect to minor repairs that might easily have been made. There was also no proper arrangement for the caretaking and I would ask you to report as to the state of repair in which you found the building and whether arrangements are now made for the lighting of the fires, and the sweeping, scrubbing, etc.

No reference is made in your report as to the condition of the ground, fences, and outbuildings. You will be good enough to report on this.

A complaint has also been made with respect to the

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

Ten years ago the Public school Inspector in his report on the No. 1 Walpole Island School stated that he considered one centrally located school on Walpole Island should be built in place of the three ungraded schools then in operation. With your approval this question was submitted to the Indian Council of the Chippewas and Pottawatomies of Walpole Island. They passed a resolution unfavourable to the establishment of the central school suggested by the Inspector. Their chief ground of objection was that in the event of a graded school being opened Indian teachers would be removed and replaced by whites. Since then education has made very little progress on the Island, chiefly owing to the inefficiency of the teachers. One of the schools has since been closed and the teacher of the No. 1 School, who has been doing good work for the short time she has been in charge of the school, has sent in her resignation to take effect on the 30th of this month. The last census return shows that there are 108 children of school age on the
the Island, with an enrolment of 80 and an average attendance of 43.

I am of opinion that if a centrally situated, two-roomed school were built, with accommodation for the teachers, similar to the one we are putting up at Rama, the children on the Island would then be in a position to obtain some lasting benefit from the schooling they would receive. Under present conditions with Indian teachers and lack of accommodation for white teachers very little advancement is made. These Indians have very little capital to their credit and would not be able to pay for the upkeep of the school, but the school vote is sufficient to meet the necessary expenditure, and if the Department would erect a building and pay the salaries the objection of the Indians to white teachers would be done away with. In fact, even under the present conditions, they have no claim to a voice in the appointment of teachers as they are only contributing $200.00 from their funds for the support of the schools.

There is some doubt as to the most suitable place for the erection of a central school. I would suggest that Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, who is an old experienced teacher and knows what the Department requires and what would be good for the Indians, should be sent there and

The Department is sending a number of Indian school teachers to the Ontario Agricultural College and the Toronto University Summer Schools and if Mr. MacKenzie were allowed to visit Walpole Island early next month he could then on his return visit these institutions and see what use the teachers were making of the privilege granted them by the Department of attending these schools. He would be able to form a good opinion of the advantage the Department will gain from this experiment.

My reason for bringing this matter to your attention at the present time is that the Indian missionary on the Reserve, Rev. Sampson Brigham, who called at the Department a short time ago, urged the necessity of something being done at once for the establishment of a central school.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

Re. establishment of consolidated school on Walpole Island.

As instructed I visited Walpole Island reaching there on Friday morning, June 27th, and leaving again on the following Monday.

I covered most of the inhabited portion of the reserve with the exception of Squirrel Island and on Monday afternoon had a meeting of the Council, at which several of the more prominent members of the Band were in attendance, when the whole question of a consolidated school was gone into. The Indians without exception were in favour of the establishment of such a school. For my own part, while fully appreciating the benefits of a consolidated school instead of two schools as on the Island at present, I am afraid that there are certain conditions there that would have a tendency to destroy the effectiveness of such an institution.

As it is now the children have long distances to walk to the two respective schools, ranging from one quarter mile to four and five, the majority being over mile.
mile from their school. I chose a site, which is the only one where I think a central school might be properly located. It is a good site with running water in a dredged cut close by. I went fully into the distances that would have to be travelled by the children and, while I could give these distances by families, a table such as that would be hard to analyze. I have, however, made a summary which shows that:—17 children would have to travel a distance of one mile or under, 38 children over one mile and under two, 45 children over two and under three and five children over three miles. You will thus see that about one half of the total number of children of school age on the reserve, which is approximately 108, would have to travel over two miles to the consolidated school. This I consider is altogether too long a walk and the only way in which it could be overcome would be to provide for the transportation of the children at least during the spring, fall and winter months. On account of the location of the Indians and the way the roads run on the reserve, it would require three conveyances to do this work to any degree of satisfaction. The question of distance is the first objection that I have to point out.

Secondly, the site of a consolidated school must of necessity be about the centre of the island. The No. 1 school
School, in which there has been a white teacher for some years, is situated at the front, close to the English Church, the agency residence and the homes of the two missionaries and the customs officer. It overlooks the main channel and in the summer time at least is not an undesirable place to live. The No. 2 or Pottawattome School is in the centre of the Island and at present taught by an Indian. As said above, a consolidated school would have to be established about the centre of the Island, a mile or so from the present No. 2 School, and would be a rather lonely place to live, as it would be about two miles from the Post Office and the residences of the people above referred to. The only white teacher we had on the Island has resigned and I feel in my own mind a little doubt as to the possibility of obtaining the services of teachers, at least two in number, who would be satisfied to live under conditions that would exist at the new school, even supposing the Department was prepared to supply them with comfortable quarters in which to reside. If we had at the present time, as we have at many of our schools that I might mention, teachers who have been in our service for sometime and who in all probability will continue therein and if they expressed
expressed a willingness to accept the conditions, then I would have no hesitancy in recommending the establishment of such a school, provided means of conveyance were found.

I suggested to the Council that, in view of the fact that their funds would not be encroached upon to build the school nor pay the salaries of the teachers to any greater extent than now, they might take into consideration the question of paying the cost of transportation, but I see that they evidently did not bring the matter up at the meeting which was held on the week following the one I attended.

I called at Sarnia to see Mr. Conn, the Public School Inspector, to ascertain his views, if he had any, in regard to the matter. Without having given the thing any serious consideration he stated that he was inclined to agree with me that there were these two obstacles at least to the establishment of a central school. Mr. Conn promised to look into the matter more fully and let the Department have his views at an early date. I think this matter might stand over for consideration till another year at least.

In the meantime, Mr. Conn is endeavouring to obtain a teacher for the No. 1 School. Presumably Mr. Sampson
Sampson, who is doing fairly good work under the circumstances at the No. 2 School, will continue in charge there. It should be possible for the Department to secure the services of a teacher for the school at the front at a somewhat later date when vacancies in the Ontario schools have been supplied, as there should be a number of teachers with limited certificates available, as those fully qualified will be given the first chance in the public schools.

If no action is to be taken certain repairs to both the No. 1 and No. 2 Schools are necessary to make them comfortable for the winter. These, however, are not extensive and the Agent can be given instructions regarding them at once.

Ottawa, January 19, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant informing the Department that you have engaged Miss Olive Stewart of Sarnia to take charge of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island at a salary of $525.00 per annum, as the applicants for this position, either of whom you were authorized to employ, were already engaged.

In reply I beg to say that you should have informed the Department as to the qualifications, experience, age and religion of Miss Stewart. The Department would like this information at once.

On the 13th instant you were informed that your request that the appointment of teachers be left in your hands could not be complied with, but, as that letter would not reach you until after the appointment of Miss Stewart was made, the Department will in this instance accept your nomination. Her permanent appointment will depend upon her success in conducting this school.

The Department has received a letter from Miss Wilson, in which she states that she was ready and willing to accept the position of teacher of this school and the Department regrets that you failed to communicate with her, as she says that she had written to you and received no reply.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant informing the Department of the illness of Miss Stewart, teacher of the No. 1 School on the Walpole Island Reserve, and that you have appointed Miss Elsie Hagedorn temporarily until such time as Miss Stewart is able to resume her duties.

Ottawa, October 29, 1915.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th instant, in which you request to be informed as to why the amount of the salary due you for the period you taught the No. 1 School on the Walpole Island Reserve during the September quarter last, has not been paid.

In reply I beg to inform you that all salaries due teachers of Indian Day Schools are paid quarterly, upon receipt of returns showing the attendance and number of days taught. If you will be good enough to prepare a return showing the attendance at this school for the period which you taught during the above named quarter and forward to the Department, through your local Indian Agent, the Department will pay you the amount of salary due for that quarter. A supply of blank forms for this purpose are enclosed herewith.

It is thought that had you applied to the agent in this matter, he would have informed you of the Department's requirements and supplied you with the necessary blank forms for making out your returns.

The Department cannot calculate the amount of salary due you for the September quarter until a return is received from you showing the number of days you taught.

A copy of the Indian Day School Regulations is also enclosed herewith for your information.

Miss E.E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Walpole Island No.1 School
Walpole Island,
Ont.

Your obedient servant
